segments.text: Phil Robertson here, they told me Hollywood doesn't want hard stories these days.
Well, my story is about as messy as they come, but it turns out our movie, The Blind,
is reaching a mighty throng out there. You break a few box office records and suddenly,
Hollywood takes notice that this is a message you'll want to hear. You're never too far
gone. God can reach you wherever you are, no matter how dark things have gotten. If you're lost,
he can give you refuge. If you weary, he can bring you strength. It was hard to watch my darkest
moments on a screen, but when I hear that people are finding hope after seeing this movie, I know
the embarrassment was worth it. I hope you'll watch The Blind and share it with someone who needs
to know it's not too late to turn it around. On The Blind today at blaisetv.com slash The Blind.
Welcome, welcome to Fearless with Jason Whitlock. I am Jason Whitlock, your host. Happy Wednesday.
Man, do we have an awesome show planned for you today. Anthony and Virgil will be here,
but only after I talk to a man that I believe is one of God's great warriors.
John MacArthur, we've had some good moments here on this show. We had Vodie Bockum in studio with us
for an interview and I love that. I've gotten to spend time with Tony Evans and Dallas and attend
his church and spend some personal time with Tony Evans. Those would be two of my highlight moments
from doing this show. And I think this next engagement with John MacArthur is going to rank
right up there with or perhaps surpass them all. We are honored to have John MacArthur,
lead pastor at Grace Church in California, Pastor MacArthur. Thank you so much for making time for
us today. And I just want to start with the documentary you guys have coming out in just two days at
Hitting Theaters, the essential church, which I think gives us a behind the scenes look at how you
and your church reacted to the COVID pandemic and the government overreached that shut down or
tried to shut down churches and tried to shut down your church. And you guys stood tall. If you would,
take a few moments just to tell us about the documentary, the essential church and what you guys are
hoping to accomplish with the release of this in two days.
Well, first of all, I need to say thanks to you. You're one of my favorites. Thanks for being a
consistent injector of Christian truth into media. I love that about you. And I do it really, Jason,
I appreciate so much your work and your conviction and your courage. It's rare. So thank you, my friend.
Well, as far as the essential church goes, we saw the church largely kind of collapse
under the lockdowns. Literally, churches shut down everywhere, and particularly in California,
it was the attack on the church was was honorous here. And, you know, people were wise enough to know
casinos and marijuana parlors, etc, etc. can be open, but a church can't be open. And they knew
this was selective, but churches continued to shut down. And I felt at the time that whatever this
whole thing turned out to be, even if it even if it was more severe from a medical standpoint than it
was, that's no reason for the church to shut down. The worse the pandemic, the more the church becomes
necessary. And when you when you realize that people are dying without ever being able to talk to
their family, the heartbreak, the loneliness, the isolation, this is the ideal time for spiritual
ministry. And we were kept out of hospitals. We were prevented from going into old age homes.
We were prevented from even visiting the homes of people in our church who were ill or struggling.
So shutting down church ministry was not just shutting down an event. It was shutting down
fellowship, the heart and soul and life of the church. So when it all kind of played out, I said
to our guys, I said, look, we need to make a documentary. We've never done that. I don't know
any church that has ever done it. But I said, we need to do that for two reasons. Reason number one
is this. We don't want somebody else writing a revisionist history about what Grace Church did.
We want to be the guys who say, this is what happened. This is the true story. This is the real story.
Rather than wait a few years and somebody writes something about it and spins it a different way,
let's let's let people see the hand of the Lord in an incredible way. And we'll put out the
documentary that is that is unassailable. And secondly, I wanted for the next time something
like this comes to try to shut down churches. I wanted people to feel guilty. I wanted pastors
to feel guilty to watch this video and say, Hey, I should have stayed open. We should have
we should have taken the side of Christ who is the head of the church. And maybe this film will put
some some courage in their hearts. And next time it comes around, they'll they'll want they'll be
eager to see the hand of God in a circumstance like we saw it. John, was your reaction and your
church's reaction to the pandemic and the the plans to shut down churches? Was it instantaneous
or was it the hypocrisy of seeing other things open, allowing protest and riots or was it as
soon as they said, hold on, shut down churches, was it an instantaneous move by you and the elders
of your church? Like we're not playing along with this. Well, yeah, I mean, my instinct was
we're not doing that. You don't have jurisdiction over the church of Jesus Christ.
You know, you stepped out of your sphere. But at the same time, we were being told that, you know,
we're going to kill grandma and grandpa, you're going to kill your wife and, you know, millions of
people are going to die. So initially, while I wanted to resist it, I had to wait to see just
exactly what the reality was. I make a comment that shows up in the film that when it was
first brought to our attention, it would have been no different than our reaction to an announcement
about a hurricane and telling people to go to the basement because we didn't know the reality of it,
but it didn't take very long. It was just a few weeks and we knew they were lying to us.
We knew the models were wrong. And I was getting a lot of input from some really very fine physicians
and epidemiologists that I know in my own life. And they were saying, this isn't real. This isn't
right. This isn't true. And I also, and Jason, you would understand this, I also trust the Lord.
And I understand the fact that the safest place you can be in a situation like that is with a whole
lot of people. So you share their diseases and you get a robust immunity. You know, the truth of
the matter was the LA Health Department at the height of this thing had to post on their website,
there was no outbreak of COVID at Grace Community Church. They were trying to shut us down. They
were trying to clear the church completely. And yet they had to say there was no outbreak of COVID.
And we were by that time, thousands of people hugging and singing and doing everything normal,
no masks, no distancing, no nothing. So I think it was gradual. I didn't believe it at the beginning
because I, you know, the flu had been around before, other viruses had been around before,
and God has designed us to be able to handle those things. And it was seemed common sense to me,
protective vulnerable people. And you know, that makes sense. So I was resistant and gradually,
as the truth began to come out, we started seeing, this is the interesting thing, we didn't announce
that church is open. I was preaching to an empty auditorium. I was looking at 3000 seats and no one
was there. I was preaching on Zoom. And all of a sudden, our people started coming back. We didn't
make an announcement. They just came back. They wanted the church. And then in a fascinating act,
the Los Angeles Police Department started coming to our church when the riots broke out.
You know, they, we have, we do police training at Grace Church. We've done it for years and years.
We let them use our campus to train. And when the county and the city and the state threatened
Grace Church, a memo went out in the LAPD, set this memo out to all the offices of the city of LA.
Any action against Grace Community Church will not be enacted by the LAPD.
So whatever they wanted to do to us, the police wouldn't join them because they,
they trusted us and because we demonstrated support of them. So here we are, a church that the city's
trying to shut down and Sunday after Sunday, it's full of policemen in uniform and their families.
That was a strange reality. So yeah, I think they weren't worried about the virus. They were so
browbeaten and hurt by the attacks on the defund the police agenda.
So you're out there on the front lines in California wrestling with Gavin Newsom. And
now that we're on the other side of this, are the people such as Gavin Newsom, are they willing to
admit they were wrong and you were right? Or are they doubling and tripling down on being wrong?
Well, they're certainly not admitting we were right and they were wrong. What politician ever
did that? But they're not really saying anything. This is a time to tuck your tail and talk about
something else. Let's drop the pandemic and try to become the president of the United States. So
let's shift gears. We don't want to re-litigate this thing because we lost. Look, at the end of
the thing, at the end of the whole lawsuit, this is the most remarkable thing of all,
they're trying to shut us down essentially for two years. We will not bow. We will not comply.
Church is packed. In fact, we were so full, we had to get a tent like a circus tent,
fill that in addition to our auditorium. We got a smaller tent, filled that. We have a gym,
filled that. The place was just jammed with people. What they wanted was to shut us down and instead,
all the other churches shut down and all the people who want to come to church are showing up in our
church. It was such a dramatic, dramatic, I guess you could say, resistance to the order.
And I think the county, the city, and Newsom decided to try to sue us, contempt of court,
fine us, threaten with jail. And we sued back. And at the end of the thing, just jump to the end,
not a long story. The county wound up losing the case. California lost the case. They had to pay
$3.5 million in all the legal fees. And they had to give us a permanent grant of exemption
from any interference by any authorities in the state of California.
Now, how do you negotiate that? How in the world can lawyers negotiate the permanent
injunction against anyone ever coming against Grace Church to close them down,
pay all $3.5 million in fees? Why would they roll over and give that when they wanted the
opposite? The answer is real clear. After 12 postponements of the hearing, we finally said,
we want a trial. Our attorney said, we want to depose all the health officials and all the city
supervisors, county supervisors. So we announced that we were going to
demand a trial and we're going to depose them. And that becomes a very, very legal act. And if
they lie under deposition, that's, you know, that's, that's a felony.
So when we announced that we were going to call for a trial 24 hours later, they said, what do you
want? And we said, we want you to go away, give us a permanent injunction to pay all fees. And they
said, okay, they did that at 24 hours rather than have to disclose the facts that really were the
facts. I look at Grace Church and I look at yourself and the way you guys handled this. And it speaks
to a message that we're constantly talking about on this show, masculinity, male leadership,
not moving in fear. If you follow God, you don't move in fear. And if you have the right male
leadership that's full of testosterone and just is, is full of that healthy masculinity that God
instilled in us, you'll make the right decisions. And so on this show, I argue that the matriarchy
and the egalitarian movement is the biggest threat facing our society civilization. And I'm just
wondering, I want to take you down the road of talking a little bit about the SBC and what's going
on with Rick Warren and whether or not I'm right or wrong that this emasculation process that they're
implementing and the silencing of men and moving men out of leadership positions is at the root
of what's destroying a lot of things we used to love and like about America.
Yeah, you are absolutely right. The destruction of male leadership leads to just everything. Feminism,
the explosion of homosexuality, transgenderism, all the chaos, the destruction of the family,
the, I mean, just look at the leadership in this nation. Every time there's an election,
the body of people that are being elected is repopulated by more women, more and more all the time,
men are marginalized. No, this has massive implications to the degree that now when we talk about our
military, we're not talking about where can we find the bravest, most courageous soldiers.
We're talking about how can we make transgender people feel comfortable in the military.
This is how deep this goes and how frightening it really is. Yeah, I would say, Jason, from a
sociological standpoint, you destroy male leadership and you will destroy a society.
And the ultimate end of that is so, is so twisted that you have men wanting to become women.
That's how far they've sung from the divine design of God. And this is not, this is not just a
preferential thing. God's design was that he made men to be the head of the house. They were to
be the providers and the protectors and the instructors and the teachers. And when, if you
want to destroy a society, just start there and masculate the society and the weaknesses,
look, I'll be real frank, if you want to know what's happened to male courage and strength,
take a look at the White House. This is the best that we can put up as a national leader above all
other people. There's no way in which you would see the current president as strong, masculine,
courageous with convictions, speaking the truth. It's the opposite of that.
So that's the, that's the, that's where you get. You finally turn over everything to the weakest
and the most corrupted or corruptible. Yeah, you're absolutely right about that. In Grace Church,
we need to say this, Grace Church is a place that love, Marx says, people say that all the time.
There's a lot of love at Grace Church. And that's important to say because we teach the Bible,
we teach it unequivocally, we teach it truthfully, and some people are offended by it.
We teach that men are the leaders and, and the architects of the present and the future of society.
We teach that God has an incredible role for women. We teach what the Scripture teaches.
And yet it's not hard-nosed. We're not unkind. We're, I think, you know, the Apostle Paul said,
the goal of our instruction is love from a pure heart. People who step into the environment here,
don't talk about the conviction at first, they talk about the love. That's what draws them here.
So you don't give up, you don't give up the sweetness of relationships by having male leadership.
You do the very opposite because there's such a sense of stability and care when you have strong
men. How do we unpack that message in a way that, and again, we're going to get criticized and,
you know, everybody, I'm a sexist pig and I'm willing to deal with that. But trust me, if, if,
when things jump off, women will be looking for guys that think like me.
But, but how do we, there will be ministers and men at churches that will watch this interview.
And I would love for you to give them advice on how, how to unpack that message of male leadership
without running off women. I think this is a particularly acute issue in a lot of black churches
because a lot of the women are unmarried. They're not covered by men. They don't have male leadership
in their home. And so it's a tiny bit more difficult for men and ministers in those congregations
to unpack that message without running the women off or greatly offending them. And maybe they
shouldn't care. I certainly don't. But if you had to give them some advice on how to sell or, or,
you know, it's really just stick to the Bible. But if you could give them some advice, please do.
Well, if I'm talking to pastors, I'm just going to, I'm just going to say what the Bible says.
And it's pretty, pretty direct act like men be strong. You go all the way back from, from Joshua
all the way through to the Apostle Paul and you, you see that same, that same thing act like men,
be courageous, be strong. I think it's the fact that you are strong in the sense of your convictions.
And that means they have to be convictions about what is right and what is true. I think the great
demand on a pastor, if he wants people to follow him for a long haul, is that they know this is a
man of conviction. People have said to me, and maybe this will illustrate it, people have said to me,
you know, you had so much courage through COVID. Where did that courage come from? And I said,
that's not courage. That's not courage. That's conviction. I know it's right. And I want to do
what's right. I'm going to do what the Word of God tells me to do. It doesn't matter what it is.
Others have said to me, how did you decide which, which issue do you resist? I mean, there's so many
of them. And I said, oh, we fight all battles. I mean, if you attack the truth and the Word of God,
we're going to defend it. It doesn't matter. What we're not looking to say is that a four or a six on
a scale of one to 10, we fight all the battles for the honor of Christ and in his church.
So I think you as a pastor, they have to see you as a man of conviction. You can't be getting rich
off of them. You can't be manipulating people. There has to be a sense in which they see the
depth of your character. And that's legitimate. I mean, that's what the Bible requires. A man of
God is to be above reproach. That's where it starts. You know, you can talk a good game.
But if you're using and abusing people or taking advantage of people or you're wavering in conviction,
you're sending a very confusing message to the people there. I think most people think of a
church service as an event and certainly in black churches, it can be a dynamic event to put it mildly.
And that is that event. But behind that, can those people trust the heart and soul of that man?
Is he Christ-like? Does he demonstrate the fruit of the Spirit? That's what provides the strength
and conviction that makes people feel safe and makes them believe that what you say is what you
really are. There's so much security in that, so much safety in that. If you want to win your
people, show them Christ in your life. This morning, Phil Robertson here, they told me Hollywood doesn't
want hard stories these days. Well, my story is about as messy as they come. But it turns out our
movie, The Blind, is reaching a mighty throng out there. You break a few box office records and suddenly
Hollywood takes notice that this is a message you'll want to hear. You're never too far gone.
God can reach you wherever you are, no matter how dark things have gotten. If you're lost,
he can give you refuge. If you weary, he can bring you strength. It was hard to watch my darkest
moments on the screen. But when I hear that people are finding hope after seeing this movie,
I know the embarrassment was worth it. I hope you'll watch The Blind and share it with someone
who needs to know it's not too late to turn it around. On The Blind today at blazetv.com slash
The Blind. When I was working out, I mean, that's how it looks so good. But on a serious note,
when I was working out, I was watching one of your sermons and you made a point in passing.
You didn't dwell on it, but you just made a point of like, hey, America is not a Christian
nation. It wasn't founded as a Christian nation. It made me pause and then you moved on. But I
wanted you to unpack why you say that because I think a lot of us do think of, well, America was
founded on biblical principles and we were a Judeo-Christian culture and it sounds like you
disagree with that. I don't disagree with that. America was founded on Judeo-Christian
principles, but nations aren't Christians. People are. So when you say this is a Christian nation,
that doesn't mean anything. Do you mean by that that the majority are Christians or do you mean by
that that the powers that be are Christians? Maybe, but the truth of the matter is nations are not
Christians. And I say that to say this, if you're depending on some kind of national Christianity
to hold the line for the truth, it's not going to happen. Because as much as we would like
to say that Christianity can sweep a nation and take over everything and make a nation righteous,
that's not possible. Even in the Old Testament, the nation of Israel with the law of God,
with all the blessings of heaven falling on them, were apostate and sinful and idolatrous and immoral.
I mean read the Old Testament, it's just constant and judgment and judgment and judgment came from
heaven on them. Even Israel, the covenant people, couldn't be a godly nation because
it's the hearts of individuals that love God, that belong to Him. So we don't want to expect too much
from the national processes in keeping us Christian. Look, there's two possibilities.
You can make laws that are Christian and that'll make people Christian. Or you make people
Christians and they make laws that reflect that. That's the only way. So the church's role is not
political, it's spiritual. This nation will change, can change when people turn to Christ.
When the mass of true believers have the fortitude, the courage and the strength
to honor Christ, when the church becomes the church, when Christian pastors and Christian
leaders stand up like men with fortitude and courage and confront the enemy and do it in love
and preach the glory of the gospel. Nations don't change from any external force,
they change from the heart inside out. Some one that has
argues every day that, hey, we have spiritual problems, not political problems. Where many
people think I go a step too far is, I've never voted for those reasons because I don't look for
political solutions to spiritual problems. And so I wanted you to, what is for a believer? What is
our proper relationship with government? What is the proper role for government in our lives?
Well, first of all, we are told to honor the king and honor those who are over us.
And Romans 13, that famous passage powers to be ordained of God. And we submit to the government,
we are, the Bible says we're to be good citizens, we're to live quiet and peaceable lives. That's
important, quiet and peaceable. So we don't riot, we don't rebel, we don't hold a revolution,
we don't get guns and shoot people, we don't march on places, we don't use, I guess you could say,
carnal weapons to gain in some way the advance of the kingdom and the word of God.
Those are not our avenues. We live godly, quiet, peaceable, submissive lives to government.
But when government oversteps its bounds, then we have to hold the line. Christ is the head of
the church, not Gavin Newsom, not any other politician. The spheres are separated. There's
the state and the church in God's design. And the state is designed to maintain social control and
protection. And the church is the church. The state can have a ruler and that's by God's design.
So you don't have anarchy. The church already has only one ruler, the Lord Jesus Christ who
mediates his rule through pastors and shepherds. So I think we have to understand that if the
church will just be the church, that's critical. Now having said that, let me add this one point,
and this is an orchard after, I have to uphold righteousness. That means if I have an opportunity
to vote for a righteous cause, I will do that. I mean, I've said it simply as this,
how can a Christian be a Democrat and go vote for those who are advocating abortion, homosexuality,
transgenderism, the mutilation of children, how can you do that? So on the other hand,
as a Christian, I find myself voting to stop that because that's a practical implication
of my biblical convictions. And it's not just that these are convictions that benefit me,
but we're talking about what honors God. And as we honor God, he blesses us. So when I vote,
I think only of one thing, where does this stand on the righteousness and evil scale?
If this is righteous, that's what I have to support. And it's not necessarily easy to do with
individuals, politicians, because some people may be Christians, some others may not be Christians,
but it comes so you can pick the person in a sense, except for the fact that if they are
advocates of evil, then I believe as a Christian, my conscience cries out to me to say, no, I have
to fight that. It does, but I got to ask a follow up. These advocates of evil is a great
position because so again, I've never voted, but I'm pretty clear that in the last election and
the one before that, I was pro-Trump. And people are like, oh, Jason, how can you be a believer
and be pro-Trump? Trump is so flawed, he's so flawed. And my position was I didn't have this phrase
advocate of evil, but what my position would be, the things that he's advocating for,
I'm not addressing his personal failings because I'm just as fallen and failed as he is,
the things that he's advocating for, I don't believe are evil, the things that I see the other side
advocating for, just as you said, abortion, the whole LGBTQ agenda. We're now looking at it in our
face. They want to put drag queens and sexualize little children. That's advocating for evil.
And whether or not Joe Biden or Donald Trump is a better person or not, is irrelevant to me,
I'm going to let God judge that. I'm trying to figure out what are they advocating and does
violate God's principles. Therefore, the principles I've had to adopt as a Christian,
that's how I make my decision. Am I thinking clearly on this?
All right, that's just crystal clear, Jason. I know you think that way. I mean, how many guys come
on Fox News and say it's demonic? I mean, you see the world through spiritual eyes. You know,
this is the apostle Paul said that. I don't know any man in the flesh anymore. I don't look at
people from the human side. I look beyond that to the spiritual realities in voting for people.
I want to know something about their moral character, something about what's in them.
But nobody's going to be sin less. So you could say Donald Trump has, I guess, pretty
blatant public demonstration of his sins in his heart.
Whereas some people mask those pretty well. If you wanted to compare the two,
Donald Trump is an open book, even to the part of him that is discouraging Joe Biden,
who appears now, maybe beyond definition in terms of corruption, puts himself out as some
virtuous individual. So you've got to get below the surface of that and it shows up in what they
advocate for. Let me ask you about your own personal legacy. And I'm sure it's probably not
something you've given a lot of thought to. But those of us that admire your work and what you're
doing and have done, we do think about that. How would you hope that people
talk about you 50 years from now when they talk about John MacArthur, what do you want
us to be saying? Hopefully, I don't think I got 50.
Now, well, what do you want us to be saying? I'd be honored if somebody said he was a friend of Jason
Whitlock. Man, you have, you made my day at the start of this and you just made my day again. I
couldn't be more flattered and all praise to God for just whatever it is I'm doing because
I'm a flawed person. But I don't have any interest in maintaining some reputation after I'm gone.
And I've said this before, but when you leave the church as a pastor, the Lord will replace you.
It's in a sense, it's like taking your hand out of a bucket of water. There's no whole,
look, God's leaders have come and gone through the years. And the only thing I could hope would
be in people's minds as they think back to John MacArthur was that he was faithful.
It's a required of a steward that a man be faithful, that he loved the Lord, that he loved his wife,
that he loved his family, he loved his kids, grandkids, great-grandkids, he loved his church.
He was a friend and most of all he was faithful to Christ. That's sufficient for me. It's a small
thing what men say about me. The final verdict will be in heaven when the Lord gives whatever
tribute is. Final thing. And I meant to ask it earlier, but I did want to get your thoughts
on the feud dispute between the SBC and Rick Warren and the Holy Galatarian issue. Do you like the way
the SBC has handled this and follow up? Are you? I'm not surprised. I'll state it this way and then
you can react. I'm not surprised that a minister could get caught up in his fame and adulation
and think that he could reinterpret the Bible. Ministers are people too and if they have too
much adulation and fame that they can make the exact same mistake. And so I see my view as I see
what's happening with Rick Warren is just a symptom of what's going on throughout society.
Man wants to be God and we've lost all humility and that's going to be that is our undoing.
Yeah, that's very sound theology. You're absolutely right. So let's just talk about Rick Warren.
You know, whatever you are as a minister is primarily defined by your view of Scripture.
If you understand Scripture as the Word of God, if you understand that you can't tamper with it,
you can't twist it, you can't alter it, or you can't treat it lightly or you can't manipulate it
because it's the holy Word of God whom he's exalted equal to his own name.
You're going to be very, very careful in handling the Word of God. In fact, there's a
seriousness in what we do. James said, stop being so many teachers for theirs is a greater
condemnation. When you stand up and say, thus says the Lord, you better not be putting words in God's
mouth and you better not be taking words out of his mouth and twisting and manipulating.
What comes across with a guy like Rick Warren or even Andy Stanley, another SPC guy, is they
in the hubris of their own pride have set themselves above the Scripture.
That's a frightening thing to me. That's really a terrifying thought because in setting yourself
above the Word of God, you have set yourself above God himself who has exalted his Word equal
to his own name. You don't see the submissiveness that should mark a faithful servant.
What's encouraging and discouraging about the SPC issue is that it's now fracturing and splitting
and it's splitting because the SPC has some people who want to use Scripture whatever way they would
like to use it and the people who want to be faithful to it and those two inevitably will split.
That's not, there's no common ground. You can't take a person who plays fast and loose with the
Bible to manipulate his own ends and somebody who is profoundly devoted to an accurate handling
of Scripture and putting it in the Word.
As to MacArthur, thank you so much for your time. It's been an honor.
I hope to make it out to California and visit your church very soon.
Just thank you again for all the work you do and thank you for honoring me and our audience with
your words today. Thank you so much.
I want to talk to you guys about my favorite partner and sponsor here, Preborn. It is my prayer
that there will come a day when abortion will be abolished. Then we will look back and see the
atrocity of what has been done. We're experiencing the impact of abortion in our lives, the breakdown
of families, the trauma that comes from a woman being pressured to have an abortion,
and the steep decline of mortality that justifies this atrocity. How then shall we respond?
Do we stand back and say, this too shall pass? Or do we rise up and say, I will stand for the innocent?
Preborn stands for the innocent, the helpless, because of your generosity.
Preborn is able to offer free ultrasounds to women. Once she hears that heartbeat,
the chance to choose life more than double. And years from now, when your grandchildren ask you,
what did you do about abortion, grandpa, grandma? You can say, I saved a life through Preborn.
I saved many lives. One ultrasound is just $28 to save a life. Just dial pound 250 and say
the keyword baby that's pound 250, keyword baby, or go to and donate my way, preborn.com
slash Jason. That's preborn.com slash Jason. You know what? In honor of John MacArthur joining us
